trans-unit.source: The Azure Table storage service stores large amounts of structured data.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Table storage service stores large amounts of structured data.

trans-unit.source: The service is a NoSQL datastore which accepts authenticated calls from inside and outside the Azure cloud.
trans-unit.target: The service is a NoSQL datastore which accepts authenticated calls from inside and outside the Azure cloud.

trans-unit.source: Azure tables are ideal for storing structured, non-relational data.
trans-unit.target: Azure tables are ideal for storing structured, non-relational data.

trans-unit.source: Common uses of the Table service include:
trans-unit.target: Common uses of the Table service include:

trans-unit.source: Storing TBs of structured data capable of serving web scale applications
trans-unit.target: Storing TBs of structured data capable of serving web scale applications

trans-unit.source: Storing datasets that don't require complex joins, foreign keys, or stored procedures and can be denormalized for fast access
trans-unit.target: Storing datasets that don't require complex joins, foreign keys, or stored procedures and can be denormalized for fast access

trans-unit.source: Quickly querying data using a clustered index
trans-unit.target: Quickly querying data using a clustered index

trans-unit.source: Accessing data using the OData protocol and LINQ queries with WCF Data Service .NET Libraries
trans-unit.target: Accessing data using the OData protocol and LINQ queries with WCF Data Service .NET Libraries

trans-unit.source: You can use the Table service to store and query huge sets of structured, non-relational data, and your tables will scale as demand increases.
trans-unit.target: You can use the Table service to store and query huge sets of structured, non-relational data, and your tables will scale as demand increases.

trans-unit.source: The Table service contains the following components:
trans-unit.target: The Table service contains the following components:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Table1</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Table1</linkText>

trans-unit.source: URL format: Code addresses tables in an account using this address format: http://.table.core.windows.net/
trans-unit.target: URL format: Code addresses tables in an account using this address format: http://.table.core.windows.net/

trans-unit.source: You can address Azure tables directly using this address with the OData protocol.
trans-unit.target: You can address Azure tables directly using this address with the OData protocol.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>OData.org</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>OData.org</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Storage Account: All access to Azure Storage is done through a storage account.
trans-unit.target: Storage Account: All access to Azure Storage is done through a storage account.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Azure Storage Scalability and Performance Targets</linkText><title></title> for details about storage account capacity.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Azure Storage Scalability and Performance Targets</linkText><title></title> for details about storage account capacity.

trans-unit.source: Table: A table is a collection of entities.
trans-unit.target: Table: A table is a collection of entities.

trans-unit.source: Tables don't enforce a schema on entities, which means a single table can contain entities that have different sets of properties.
trans-unit.target: Tables don't enforce a schema on entities, which means a single table can contain entities that have different sets of properties.

trans-unit.source: The number of tables that a storage account can contain is limited only by the storage account capacity limit.
trans-unit.target: The number of tables that a storage account can contain is limited only by the storage account capacity limit.

trans-unit.source: Entity: An entity is a set of properties, similar to a database row.
trans-unit.target: Entity: An entity is a set of properties, similar to a database row.

trans-unit.source: An entity can be up to 1MB in size.
trans-unit.target: An entity can be up to 1MB in size.

trans-unit.source: Properties: A property is a name-value pair.
trans-unit.target: Properties: A property is a name-value pair.

trans-unit.source: Each entity can include up to 252 properties to store data.
trans-unit.target: Each entity can include up to 252 properties to store data.

trans-unit.source: Each entity also has 3 system properties that specify a partition key, a row key, and a timestamp.
trans-unit.target: Each entity also has 3 system properties that specify a partition key, a row key, and a timestamp.

trans-unit.source: Entities with the same partition key can be queried more quickly, and inserted/updated in atomic operations.
trans-unit.target: Entities with the same partition key can be queried more quickly, and inserted/updated in atomic operations.

trans-unit.source: An entity's row key is its unique identifier within a partition.
trans-unit.target: An entity's row key is its unique identifier within a partition.

trans-unit.target: ./media/storage-table-concepts-include/table1.png

trans-unit.target: http://www.odata.org/
